# Coat of arms of Berlin

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Jump to: navigation, search

Coat of arms of Berlin  
---  
[![Coat of arms of
Berlin.svg](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d9/Coat_of_arms_of_Berlin.svg/150px-
Coat_of_arms_of_Berlin.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Coat_of_arms_of_Berlin.svg)  
Versions  
[![Country symbol of Berlin
color.svg](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e6/Country_symbol_of_Berlin_color.svg/135px-
Country_symbol_of_Berlin_color.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Country_symbol_of_Berlin_color.svg)
Escutcheon-only version  
Details  
[Armiger](/wiki/Armiger "Armiger") | City of [Berlin](/wiki/Berlin "Berlin")  
[Crest](/wiki/Crest_\(heraldry\) "Crest \(heraldry\)") | A city coronet Or with five leaves and a gate  
[Escutcheon](/wiki/Escutcheon_\(heraldry\) "Escutcheon \(heraldry\)") | Argent a bear rampant [Sable](/wiki/Sable_\(heraldry\) "Sable \(heraldry\)") langued and armed [Gules](/wiki/Gules_\(heraldry\) "Gules \(heraldry\)")  
Use | The state logo may be used by the general public while the coat of arms proper is only eligible for use with authorities.  
  
The [coat of arms](/wiki/Coat_of_arms "Coat of arms") of [Berlin](/wiki/Berlin
"Berlin") is used by the [German](/wiki/Germany "Germany") [city
state](/wiki/City_state "City state") as well as the city itself. Introduced
in 1954 for [West Berlin](/wiki/West_Berlin "West Berlin"), it shows a black
[bear](/wiki/Bear_in_heraldry "Bear in heraldry") on a white shield. On top of
the shield is a special crown, created by the amalgamation of the [mural
crown](/wiki/Mural_crown "Mural crown") of a city with the so-called [people's
crown](/wiki/People%27s_crown "People's crown") (_Volkskrone_), used in
Germany to denote a republic. Berlin's various boroughs use their own emblems.

The bear has been used as a charge in the Berlin coat of arms since 1709,
formerly alongside the [eagles](/wiki/Eagle_\(heraldry\) "Eagle \(heraldry\)")
of [Brandenburg](/wiki/Brandenburg "Brandenburg") and [Prussia](/wiki/Prussia
"Prussia").[1] A bear occurs on seals, coins and signet rings from as early as
the late 12th century (but not as heraldic charge before 1709), presumably due
to a [canting](/wiki/Canting_arms "Canting arms") association with the city's
name.[2]

##
History[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Coat_of_arms_of_Berlin&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: History")]

The oldest preserved and known seal of Berlin is from 1253. It depicts the
[Brandenburg Eagle](/wiki/Coat_of_arms_of_Brandenburg "Coat of arms of
Brandenburg") spreading its wings in a [clover](/wiki/Clover "Clover")-shaped
[archway](/wiki/Arch "Arch"). The text on the seal is `SIGILLVM DE BERLIN
BVRGENSIVM` (seal of Berlin's citizens). It supposedly was the seal of
Berlin's first [mayor](/wiki/Mayor "Mayor") Marsilius.

A later seal dated to 1280 shows bears as [supporters](/wiki/Supporters
"Supporters") of the Brandenburg coat of arms. The bear appears to have risen
in popularity during the 17th century, with an early depiction on a coat of
arms in a signet ring dated 1603, and it was adopted as a heraldic charge in
1709. The shield was now divided in three parts, showing the bear below the
eagles of Brandenburg and Prussia. Heraldist Adolf Matthias Hildebrandt in
1883 designed a number of proposals for a new coat of arms. One of these was
the simplified _azure a bear rampant sable_ with a [mural
crown](/wiki/Mural_crown "Mural crown") in the crest. This was in use as minor
coat of arms from 1920, and was adopted as the only coat of arms of [West
Berlin](/wiki/West_Berlin "West Berlin") in 1954, while [East
Berlin](/wiki/East_Berlin "East Berlin") continued to use the design of 1935.

## State
logo[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Coat_of_arms_of_Berlin&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: State logo")]

To enable civilians and non-governmental institutions to express their
affinity with Berlin, the Senate of the Interior and Sports provided a logo
which features the arms' shield without the crown in black and white or
coloured versions.

## Legal
status[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Coat_of_arms_of_Berlin&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: Legal status")]

The coat of arms was laid down in a law of 1954:

> § 1 (1) The coat of arms shows on a silver (white) shield, a black bear
> rampant with tongue and claws in red. On the shield rests a golden five
> leaved crest coronet, whose tiara of brickwork is provided with a gate in
> the center. ... § 4 Decisive for the design of the state's coat of arms, the
> state’s flag... are the patterns, added to this law. According to the
> state’s coat of arms, an artistic design is reserved to special purposes.
>
> — Federal Government, Law on the State Symbols of the State of Berlin of 13
> May 1954 (GVBl. S. 289) [3]

## Symbol of
Berlin[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Coat_of_arms_of_Berlin&action=edit&section=4
"Edit section: Symbol of Berlin")]

The bear has come to be used as the mascot of Berlin, and was used almost
excessively by local authorities, so that Hans Brendicke, editor of the
journal of the Historical Society of Berlin, in 1896 remarked on the ubiquity
of badly designed bears in Berlin. A member of the Historical Society went on
to collect a total of 273 different representations of bears in Berlin.
Hildebrandt in 1915 again complained about the excesses of variation in the
bear, especially deviation from the Prussian tincture of black on white.[4]

The bear has remained the city's mascot,[5] and in 2001 has been developed
into the so-called _[Berlin Buddy Bears](/wiki/United_Buddy_Bears "United
Buddy Bears")_ , fiberglass sculptures of bears first introduced in 2001, have
been used to promote the qualities of "tolerance" and _Weltoffenheit_
(cosmopolitanism) associated with the city.

[The Berlin Buddy Bear](/wiki/United_Buddy_Bears "United Buddy Bears")
